statement.tex: \text{Find an anti derivative (or integral) of } \\ \sin 2x - 4 \, e^{3x}\text{ by the method of inspection.}

step.context: \text{If }\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)=g(x)\text{, is this the} \\ \text{anti-derivative (or integral) of $g(x)$ is?}
step.reason: \text{Anti-derivative or integral is the reverse of}\\ \text{differentiation. Therefore, when }\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)=g(x)\\ \text{then integral of }g(x)=f(x).

\dfrac{d\cos x}{dx}=-\sin x \text{ and }\dfrac{de^x}{dx}=e^x \\ \text{Applying the above using Chain Rule:} \\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}\cos nx &= \dfrac{d}{d nx}\cos nx\cdot \dfrac{d}{dx}nx \\ &= -\sin nx\cdot n \\ &= -n\sin nx \end{align} \\ \therefore {\bf \dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\dfrac{-\cos nx}{n}\right)=\sin nx }\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}e^{mx} &= \dfrac{d}{d mx}e^{mx}\cdot \dfrac{d}{dx}mx \\ &= e^{mx}\cdot m \\ &= me^{mx} \end{align} \\ \therefore {\bf \dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\dfrac{e^{mx}}{m}\right)=e^{mx}}
